explanation:
To decide whether any operation in OS_CondVarBroadcast is dead (i.e., can be removed without changing program behaviour) the analyzer must know the semantics and side-effects of the called routines, the control constants and the types involved: 

- OS_ObjectIdGetById: Determines whether the call has observable side-effects (state changes, transactions, logging, error conditions) and under what conditions it returns OS_SUCCESS. If this call has side-effects, its removal would change behavior; conversely, if it is a pure query whose results are unused, it might be dead.

- OS_CondVarBroadcast_Impl: The conditional call is the candidate for dead-code analysis. Need its implementation to know whether it performs any observable actions (wakes tasks, changes global state, I/O). If it is a no-op, the call would be dead.

- OS_SUCCESS: The value tested controls whether the Impl call executes. Knowing its definition and any related error-code semantics is necessary to reason about reachability of the Impl call and whether the conditional is meaningful.

- OS_object_token_t: The type of token passed to the Impl may carry ownership/locking semantics or have side-effects on construction/destruction; its representation can affect whether creating/filling the token is observable.

- osal_id_t: Type of var_id; needed to reason about value ranges, validity checks inside OS_ObjectIdGetById and whether certain inputs always lead to the same path (e.g., always failing), which would make subsequent code dead.

- OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE and OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR: Constants passed to OS_ObjectIdGetById that can alter that function's behaviour (e.g., selecting different validation/locking paths). Their meanings affect whether OS_ObjectIdGetById has side-effects for this call-site.

- UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType, UT_Stub_RegisterContextWithMetaData, UT_ExecuteBasicHandler, UT_Stub_GetReturnValuePtr: These unit-test/stub framework functions are listed in the static call graph as callees of this function (instrumentation or macro expansion may invoke them). They may introduce observable side-effects (registration, handler execution) even if the visible source looks trivial. Their behaviour must be known to determine if any statements in OS_CondVarBroadcast are actually doing work.

- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: Called by OS_CondVarBroadcast_Impl (per the call graph). Its behaviour may determine whether the Impl call does anything observable; include it to trace side-effects inside Impl.

- OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit, OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex, OS_ObjectIdConvertToken, OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel: These are internal callees of OS_ObjectIdGetById (per the call graph). They may start/cancel transactions or otherwise modify global/system state. To decide if OS_ObjectIdGetById (and thus the surrounding code) is dead, the analyzer must know whether any of these internal operations produce observable effects that would be removed if the call were deleted.

Including these symbols (the direct callees, the constants/types used at the call site, and the immediate callees of those callees shown in the static graph) provides the minimal context needed to determine whether removing any executed operation in OS_CondVarBroadcast would change runtime behaviour (i.e., to decide if it is dead code).
